hints_html: Simply plug in n = 0 in your formula for cn from part (b).
hints_latex:
Simply plug in \emph{n = 0} in your formula for
\emph{c\textsubscript{n}} from
{part
(b)}.
hints_raw: Simply plug in ''n = 0'' in your formula for ''c<sub>n</sub>'' from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2012/Question_04_(b)|part (b)]].
question: 4 (c)
sols_html:
From part (b) we have the formula \(c_n=\int_{0}^{1}f(t)e^{-2\pi int}\,dt.\) Plugging in n = 0 we calculate

\[\begin{aligned} c_0 &= \int_{0}^{1}f(t)e^{-2\pi i(0)t}\,dt \\ &= \int_{0}^{1}(t^2-t)(1)dt \\ &=\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{2}=-\frac{1}{6}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Consider the Fourier series

\[\begin{aligned} t^2 - t = \sum_{n = -\infty}^\infty c_ne^{2\pi int}\end{aligned}\]

for \(0 \leq t \leq 1\).

(c) Compute the coefficient c0.
statement_raw:
Consider the Fourier series

:<math>
t^2 - t = \sum_{n = -\infty}^\infty c_ne^{2\pi int}
</math>

for <math>0 \leq t \leq 1</math>.

'''(c)''' Compute the coefficient ''c<sub>0</sub>''.
